If you don't see the menu bar on top, press the ALT key.

Go to Settings > Forwarding and IMAP > Let Devices & Apps use IMAP and enable that.

content:
Try closing TB and deleting the parent.lock file in the profile folder.

To open your TB profile:

- TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

- click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

If that doesn't work:

Close TB and open the Profile manager. Select the profile you want to use by default > check 'Use the selected profile...' > click 'Start Thunderbird'. 

Also make sure TB menu > Settings > General > System Integration > 'Always check to see...' is enabled and click the 'Check Now' button.
creator: siffemoz

content: Just uninstall Thunderbird altogether via the OS interface. In Win11, that would be found by clicking the Start button and searching for: installed apps. Scroll down to Mozilla Thunderbird > click the meatball menu (...) to the right > Uninstall. Also delete user data if prompted to do so.
creator: siffemoz

content:
Are you referring to an account password or the Primary password?

If it's the primary password, here are instructions:

  1. Choose Tools -> Developer Tools > Error Console, paste the expression: 
  openDialog("chrome://pippki/content/resetpassword.xhtml")
  1. the, press the Evaluate button. That will open a dialog asking you if you want to reset your password. If Evaluate is not seen, press enter key.
  2. When prompted, press the Reset button.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password#w_resetting-your-primary-password-if-you-have-forgotten-it

All account passwords will be deleted and will need to be reentered.

If the problem is your email account password, you need to contact your email provider to reset it
creator: davidsk

content:
It appears that your profile didn't get moved or was only partially moved. You can import the addressbook by clicking tools>import>import from a file and follow the menus for addressbook, select the sqlite option and then locate and select the abook.sqlite file from your old profile. Repeat the steps for the history.sqlite file.

I presume your email account is POP. Copying the messages from the inbox and Sent folders is messy when not part of the initial transfer. Here are steps that will at least make them accessible: - install the importexporttools NG addon - highlight Local Folders - rightclick and select the importexport option to import mbox - now locate the Mail folder on old profile - then, click the POP account folder - now, click the inbox file (IGNORE the msf file) and import it - repeat the steps for the Sent file (again, ignore the msf entry
creator: davidsk

content: click tools>import>import from a file and then follow the menus for addressbook and select the sqlite option and then locate and select the abook.sqlite file from old profile. Repeat the process for the history.sqlite file. AND, if you're comfortable with windows file explorer, just exit thunderbird, and copy the abook.sqlite and history.sqlite files from old profile and paste into new profile and restart thunderbird.
creator: davidsk

content: If you can start thunderbird on old PC, do this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird - you are now in the profile. note the exact location on the disc. you are in the folder with abook.sqlite and history.sqlite. copy both to external media and you can then follow previous steps to import to your new pc.
creator: davidsk
